ai-mn3:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-mn3:2.1_0: “Mendicants, be my heirs in the teaching, not in material things.
ai-mn3:2.2_0: Out of compassion for you, I think,
ai-mn3:2.3_0: ‘How can my disciples become heirs in the teaching, not in material things?’
ai-mn3:2.4_0: If you become heirs in material things, not in the teaching, they’ll point to you, saying,
ai-mn3:2.5_0: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in the teaching, not in material things.’
ai-mn3:2.6_0: And they’ll point to me, saying,
ai-mn3:2.7_0: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in the teaching, not in material things.’
ai-mn3:2.8_0: If you become heirs in the teaching, not in material things, they’ll point to you, saying,
ai-mn3:2.9_0: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in the teaching, not in material things.’
ai-mn3:2.10_0: And they’ll point to me, saying,
ai-mn3:2.11_0: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in the teaching, not in material things.’
ai-mn3:2.12_0: So, mendicants, be my heirs in the teaching, not in material things.
ai-mn3:2.13_0: Out of compassion for you, I think,
ai-mn3:2.14_0: ‘How can my disciples become heirs in the teaching, not in material things?’
ai-mn3:3.1_0: Suppose that I had eaten and refused more food, being full, and having had as much as I need.
ai-mn3:3.2_0: And there was some extra alms-food that was going to be thrown away.
ai-mn3:3.3_0: Then two mendicants were to come who were weak with hunger.
ai-mn3:3.5_0: ‘Mendicants, I have eaten and refused more food, being full, and having had as much as I need.
ai-mn3:3.6_0: And I have some extra alms-food that’s going to be thrown away.
ai-mn3:3.7_0: Eat it if you like. Otherwise I’ll throw it out where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.’
ai-mn3:3.9_0: ‘The Buddha has eaten and refused more food.
ai-mn3:3.10_0: And he has some extra alms-food that’s going to be thrown away.
ai-mn3:3.11_0: If we don’t eat it he’ll throw it away.
ai-mn3:3.13_0: “Be my heirs in the teaching, not in material things.”
ai-mn3:3.14_0: And alms-food is a kind of material thing.
ai-mn3:3.15_0: Why don’t I get almsfood by this almsfood?’
ai-mn3:3.17_0: Then the second of those mendicants thought,
ai-mn3:3.18_0: ‘The Buddha has eaten and refused more food.
ai-mn3:3.19_0: And he has some extra alms-food that’s going to be thrown away.
ai-mn3:3.20_0: If we don’t eat it he’ll throw it away.
ai-mn3:3.21_0: Why don’t I eat almsfood before eating?’
ai-mn3:3.23_0: Even though that mendicant, after eating the alms-food, spent the day and night rid of hunger and weakness, it is the former mendicant who is more worthy of respect and praise.
ai-mn3:3.25_0: Because for a long time that will conduce to that mendicant being of few wishes, content, self-effacing, unburdensome, and energetic.
ai-mn3:3.26_0: So, mendicants, be my heirs in the teaching, not in material things.
ai-mn3:3.27_0: Out of compassion for you, I think,
ai-mn3:3.28_0: ‘How can my disciples become heirs in the teaching, not in material things?’”
ai-mn3:4.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn3:4.2_0: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
ai-mn3:4.3_0: Then soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Sāriputta said to the mendicants,
ai-mn3:5.1_0: “Reverends, how do the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion not train in seclusion? And how do the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion?”
ai-mn3:5.2_0: “Reverend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta.
ai-mn3:5.4_0: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-mn3:5.5_0: “Well then, reverends, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-mn3:6.1_0: “Reverends, how do the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion not train in seclusion?
ai-mn3:6.2_0: The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.
ai-mn3:6.3_0: They don’t give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.
ai-mn3:6.4_0: They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.
ai-mn3:6.5_0: In this case, the senior mendicants should be criticized on three grounds.
ai-mn3:6.6_0: ‘The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.’
ai-mn3:6.8_0: ‘They don’t give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.’
ai-mn3:6.10_0: ‘They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.’
ai-mn3:6.12_0: The senior mendicants should be criticized on these three grounds.
ai-mn3:6.13_0: In this case, the middle mendicants
ai-mn3:6.14_0: and the junior mendicants should be criticized on the same three grounds.
ai-mn3:6.15_0: ‘The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.’
ai-mn3:6.17_0: ‘They don’t give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.’
ai-mn3:6.19_0: ‘They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.’
ai-mn3:6.21_0: The mendicants shouldn’t be criticized on these three grounds.
ai-mn3:6.22_0: This is how the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.
ai-mn3:7.1_0: And how do the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion?
ai-mn3:7.2_0: The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.
ai-mn3:7.3_0: They give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.
ai-mn3:7.4_0: They’re not indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.
ai-mn3:7.5_0: In this case, the senior mendicants should be praised on three grounds.
ai-mn3:7.6_0: ‘The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.’
ai-mn3:7.8_0: ‘They give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.’
ai-mn3:7.10_0: ‘They’re not indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.’
ai-mn3:7.12_0: The senior mendicants should be praised on these three grounds.
ai-mn3:7.13_0: In this case, the middle mendicants
ai-mn3:7.14_0: and the junior mendicants should be praised on three grounds.
ai-mn3:7.15_0: ‘The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.’
ai-mn3:7.17_0: ‘They give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.’
ai-mn3:7.19_0: ‘They’re not indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.’
ai-mn3:7.21_0: The mendicants shouldn’t be praised on these three grounds.
ai-mn3:7.22_0: This is how the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.
ai-mn3:8.1_0: The bad thing here is greed and hate.
ai-mn3:8.2_0: There is a middle way of greed, hate, and delusion.
ai-mn3:8.3_0: And what is that middle way of practice?
ai-mn3:8.5_0: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
ai-mn3:8.6_0: This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.

ai-mn3:9-15.8_0: There is a middle way of practice for giving up vanity and negligence. It gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-mn3:9-15.9_0: And what is that middle way of practice?
ai-mn3:9-15.11_0: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
ai-mn3:9-15.12_0: This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.”
ai-mn3:9-15.13_0: This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.
ai-mn3:9-15.14_0: and those monks were uplifted and greatly rejoiced in venerable Sāriputta’s words.
ai-mn3:9-15.15_0: The third section on the Teaching is finished.
